section.title: Short History of Plugin Support
section.p: The initial support for plugins was primitive, it allowed adding a contextual menu action in the Text editing mode for manipulating the selected content: .
In version 11.2 the Workspace Access plugin type was added: .

Workspace Access plugins allow you to add custom toolbar and menu actions, custom side views and add various behaviors depending on various events which occur in the application (documents are opened, closed, saved, the application is started or closed). They can be implemented either in Java or Javascript.

Originally plugins could be manually installed by being copied to the OXYGEN_INSTALL_DIR\plugins. Around version 14 we added support to pack plugins and frameworks as add-onsand thus automate the installation process.

section.title: Short History of Frameworks Support
section.p: The concept of framework appeared around version 9.
A framework is a means to group together resources for editing and validating a specific XML vocabulary: .
In version 16 we added support to extend a base framework, extension which can afterwards be bundled as an add-on.

section.title: Private Hosted Plugins and Frameworks
section.p: Content Management Systems like Astoria, Bluestream, Ixiasoft, SDL have implemented plugins which allow to connect to their servers.
There are also probably lots of privately owned frameworks used for editing various varieties of XML documents inside companies.

section.title: Why are we (the team) working on add-ons?
section.p: Open source add-ons are useful as samples for third parties.
Add-ons can be released at a much faster pace.
Interns who work for us for a couple of months are not allowed to work on the main code.
We can work on add-ons before releases when we enter a code freeze stage.
